awd_titl_txt: Developing Certificates in Technical Art & Photogrammetry and Technical Animation
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support development of certificate programs in Technical Art & Photogrammetry and in Technical Animation.  The project goal is to train technicians who have the critical knowledge and skills in art and programming that are needed for the design and development of realistic simulations for virtual and augmented reality. The project has significant industry involvement to ensure that both faculty and students gain industry-relevant experience, and to ensure that students who earn the certificates are fully prepared to enter the workforce. The project addresses the need to develop technicians with the ability to produce the sophisticated user interfaces, simulations, and training systems demanded by the future of work in a broad array of fields, including education, medicine, law enforcement, and engineering.

The project has six objectives. First, it will use a "developing a curriculum" (DACUM)-based process to create rigorous, project-based courses in operation, utilization, and programming using highly-technical hardware and software. Second, it will place faculty in industry externships to improve and update their skills and abilities, allowing them to share real-world experience with students. Third, four new courses will be created as part of two new certificate programs. The certificates will incorporate components such as work-based learning/job shadowing, industry tours, and employability-skills practice throughout the program. Fourth, the project will create a training studio for motion capture and photogrammetry. The studio will incorporate multiple stationary cameras around a moving object covered in data-capturing "dots" to convert data into 3D animations. It will also use data from multiple 2-D photographs of a stationary object at different angles to create three-dimensional output. This studio will provide students with hands-on, industry-valued skills and experience. Fifth, the project will increase diversity across the entire program through targeted, evidence-based practices aimed at recruiting and retaining higher percentages of students from populations, such as women and veterans, that are under-represented in STEM technical fields. Sixth, the project will utilize external formative and summative evaluation to monitor project success and make iterative programmatic improvements.  Descriptive statistics and inferential statistics will be utilized as a part of the evaluation.  Data will be collected and analyzed to determine annually whether the stated outcomes have been met.  In addition, the evaluation and project teams will provide annual reports on relevant quantitative measures of project success based upon enrollment, certificate completion, industry placement, degrees earned, and pass rates for the four new courses. The project estimates that more than 200 students will enroll in the four new courses over the course of the project. Additional students will benefit from the increased industry involvement in technician education programs, including studio tours, mock interviews, and portfolio presentations.  This project is funded by NSF's Advanced Technological Education program, which focuses on the education of technicians for the high-technology fields that drive our nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Developing Certificates in Technical Art & Photogrammetry and Technical Animation project was funded with a National Science Foundation grant for $505,103, which includes a supplemental grant to fund student internship projects. The project ran for three and a half years including a six-month extension due to delays as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. This grant allowed the Simulation and Game Development department at Wake Technical Community College (Wake Tech) to develop new curriculum for emerging technologies in Simulation and Game Development. The emerging technologies we focused on were photogrammetry, motion capture, technical art, and advanced 3D animation techniques.

Four new courses were developed and three were added to the common curriculum library for North Carolina Community Colleges as a part of this project (motion capture, photogrammetry, tech art, and 3D animation II). Two new Wake Tech certificates were created based around the new classes. The grant allowed three professors to participate in externships at local companies: Epic Games and RTI International, to learn new techniques in motion capture and photogrammetry. The content of each new course was developed based on the experiences in the externships and guidance from local professionals working in the field.

A major part of the project was the creation of the Simulation and Game Development (SGD) Technical Studio on Wake Tech?s southern campus, which features a professional quality motion capture stage and four photography studios. Students take classes in this space that focus on motion capture or photogrammetry. Students from North Carolina State University (NCSU) have also used the space to work on school projects. Wake Tech students participating in grant-funded internships used the space and equipment for their projects.

The supplemental grant funded three student internship projects at Wake Tech. The Culinary, Cyber Security, and Early Childhood Development departments at Wake Tech served as clients for the students after impacts from the COVID-19 pandemic prevented external internships. Fifteen students used the newly acquired skills from the newly developed classes to develop learning simulations as part of their internship. All three simulations are now available for students to use.

With a focus on outreach and dissemination of project success, professors presented at various conferences including SIGGRAPH, East Coast Games Conference, and the North Carolina Community College System Conference. Professors also attended open house events at local high schools to talk about the program and the new classes and invited high school students to visit the grant-funded studio.

The grant team wrote a case study that demonstrates how professors? experience in externships affected the development of the photogrammetry course. Students who took the course and then participated in the internships felt confident in their abilities in photogrammetry and were successful in their internships.

This grant project allowed Wake Tech?s SGD department to ?level up.? Professors worked with local industry to develop innovative courses. A professional-quality technical studio was developed for students to train on. Students gained valuable experience through internships. The SGD department was originally created with an NSF ATE grant (FAIN 0602801) in 2006 and continues to grow and be a leader in game development education at community colleges.

 


Last Modified: 06/20/2023
Modified by: Amber M Johnson
